TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested on suspicion of having murdered , in DATE , Mr GPE , whose mother became Speaker of ORG in DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE he was remanded on the basis of DATE detention orders issued by ORG . The detention orders set out as grounds for his detention the fact that he had been suspected of having committed a serious offence punishable by DATE imprisonment ; moreover , the isolation of the suspect from society was considered necessary because he might abscond and obstruct the criminal investigation by influencing the witnesses .

CARDINAL . In his appeals against the detention orders , the applicant argued , inter alia , that his detention was not necessary since there were no objective reasons to suspect him , that during his detention no investigation measures had been carried out and that he suffered from epilepsy and needed specialist medical treatment .

CARDINAL . All his appeals were dismissed on the ground that the circumstances warranting his detention had not changed . On DATE the ORG reduced the duration of the detention order from DATE to DATE on the ground that “ during DATE no investigation measures were carried out ... the suspect did not have a criminal record , he has a family and minor children , a house , a job and serious health problems . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG submitted the applicant 's case file to the competent court . After that date the applicant continued to be detained without any detention order .

CARDINAL . On DATE a habeas corpus request lodged by the applicant was rejected and he continued to be detained in pre - trial detention until DATE , when he was convicted and sentenced to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . NORP The relevant domestic law has been set out in the ORG 's judgments in the cases of ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) .
